chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para:
These instructions will guide you through installing and running an HPCC
High Performance Computing Cluster (HPCC) is a massively parallel processing computing platform that solves Big Data problems. See http://hpccsystems.com/Why-HPCC/How-it-works for more details. System on a single node inside a Linux virtual machine running on a Windows host.

Packaged to run inside a virtual machine, this version provides a hands-on experience with an HPCC system. You can experiment with it and even create real-world data analytics applications-all on your desktop or laptop PC.

This version includes the tools and functionality of an HPCC without the need for a physical cluster of servers. It provides enough for you to evaluate an HPCC system and learn to use ECL
Enterprise Control Language (ECL) is a declarative, data-centric programming language used to manage all aspects of the massive data joins, sorts, and builds that truly differentiate HPCC (High Performance Computing Cluster) from other technologies in its ability to provide flexible data analysis on a massive scale. . Naturally, you do not get the power of parallel processing, but you can use this version as an evaluation, learning, and experimentation tool.

row.entry: Reading this document in its entirety before beginning. The steps in this document can take an hour or two, depending on your download speed.

sect1.title: System Requirements
sect1.para: Running HPCC in a virtual machine requires (at minimum):

listitem.para: A personal computer running Windows XP, Vista, Windows 7 (either 32- or 64-bit)
A minimum of 2 GB ram, with at least 1.5 GB of free memory available. We recommend 4 GB or more
Intel Pentium D (or better) or AMD Athlon64/Opteron/Phenom processor
Minimum 5 GB of available disk space, we recommend 20 GB
A virtualization software package: VMware® Player or Server (version 4.0 or later) or Oracle VM VirtualBox (version 4.0 or later).
Internet Explorer® 8, Google Chrome 10, or Firefox™ 3.0 (or later)

sect1.para: Users should have familiarity with installing and running Windows applications.

chapter.title: Getting the Tools and the VM Image
chapter.para: To run the virtual machine version of the HPCC System, you need virtualization software. These packages allow you to run virtual images inside a single host. There are a several different vendors who make virtualization software, while any or all of these could work, we support the following products:

listitem.para: VMware's Virtual Machine
Oracle's VM VirtualBox

sect1.title: VMware Virtual Machine
sect1.para: The VMware player from VMware® is a virtualization software you can use to run the HPCC virtual machine.
In the following sections, you will:

Download and install the VMware Player
Download the HPCC virtual machine image from HPCC Systems.
Open and import the image in the VMware Player
Once you have completed these steps, you can evaluate the HPCC Platform and learn how to use it.

sect2.title: Download and Install the VMware Player
sect2.para: If you already have VMware Player installed, you can skip this section and go to .

listitem.para: Go to the VMware site: http://www.vmware.com/products/player/.
Click on download link, then follow the instructions to download the VMware Player for 32-bit and 64-bit Windows.
Registration is required, but the player is free.
Download the VMware Player (save to a folder on your machine).
Follow VMware's on-screen instructions and install the VMware Player.

sect2.title: Get the latest HPCC Virtual Image File

listitem.para: Download the latest HPCC virtual machine image file from:
You may need to register to login.
Save the file to a folder on your machine.
Open the VMware Player.
From the Player menu, select File, then Open...
Go to the folder where you saved the downloaded file and select it.
For example (HPCCSystemsVM-n.n.n.n.ova , where n.n.n.n is the version number).
The .ova file should open an Import Virtual Machine dialog window providing for the name of the new virtual machine, and the storage path of the virtual machine you selected. Import Virtual Machine
Press the Import button to import the virtual machine into the VMware Player.
Wait for the HPCC virtual machine to load to the desktop in the VMware player. This may take a few minutes.
The first time you use the VM Player, you must accept the license agreement. You may also be prompted to install add-ons, but they are not necessary for the HPCC virtual machine.
At the VMware Player main window the new virtual machine you just imported is now listed. Double-click on that virtual machine to start it.
Once the VM initialization completes, you will see a window similar to the following:

sect1.title: VM VirtualBox
sect1.para: Oracle's virtualization software, VM VirtualBox is supported for running the HPCC virtual machine image.
In the following section(s), you will:

Download the HPCC virtual machine image from HPCC Systems.

sect2.title: Download and Install the VM VirtualBox
sect2.para: If you already have the VM VirtualBox installed, skip to step number 6, and verify the network configuration settings.

Download the VirtualBox Installation file. Save to a folder on your machine.
Double-click on the installation file to install VirtualBox.
Follow the on-screen instructions to complete the installation of VirtualBox.
Start the VM VirtualBox application.
From the File menu, select Preferences...
The VirtualBox - Settings dialog displays. VirtualBox - Settings
Select Network from the list on the left side of the window.
Double-click on the VirtualBox Host-Only Ethernet Adaptor.

From the Network Details window, select the DHCP Server Tab and check the Enable Server box. Network Details
Note:
You may need to add IP Address values to the Lower Address Bound and Upper Address Bound fields. The address the VM uses is in the private IP address range of 192.168.x.x
Press the OK button on the Network Details dialog box, then press the OK button on the VirtualBox - Settings box.

listitem.para: Download the latest HPCC virtual machine image file from:
You may need to register to login.
Save the file to a folder on your machine.
Open VM VirtualBox.
From the File menu select Import Appliance... (Ctrl + I)
Press the Open appliance button from the dialog to select the appliance to import.
Navigate to the folder where you saved the downloaded file and select it.

Select the Network menu option. On the Adapter 1 tab check the Enable Network Adapter box, and set the Attached to: option to NAT. VM VirtualBox Network Adapter 1

From the same Network - Settings window, select the tab for Adapter 2. Check the Enable Network Adapter box, and set the Attached to: option to Host-only Adapter.
Press the OK button.

Double-click on that virtual machine to start it.

chapter.title: Running the HPCC VM
chapter.para:
In this section, we will access the HPCC using the web-based interface: ECL Watch
ECL Watch is a Web-based interface to your HPCC system. It enables you to examine and manage many aspects of the HPCC and allows you to see information about jobs you run, data files, and system metrics. .From ECL Watch, we will download the ECL IDE
The ECL IDE (Integrated Development Environment) is the tool used to create queries into your data and ECL files with which to build your queries. This is a Windows application. . If you already have the ECL IDE installed, you can skip this section and continue at Running the HPCC ECL IDE when you had a previous version installed.

listitem.para: In your browser, go to the ECL Watch URL displayed (circled in red) in Figure 1, VM Welcome Screen. For example, http://nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn:8010, where nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn is your Virtual Machine's IP address.

row.entry: Your virtual IP address could be different from the ones provided in the example images. Please use the IP address provided by your installation.

listitem.para: From ECL Watch page, click on the Resources link in the menu on the left side.
Follow the link to the HPCC System's portal.
Click on the ECL IDE link.
Download the ECL IDE for Windows from the Community ECL IDE download page.
Install the ECL IDE, following the prompts in the installation program. Once the ECL IDE is installed successfully, you can proceed.

sect1.title: Write some ECL
sect1.para: Let's write, compile, and execute a simple "Hello World" program on our HPCC.

listitem.para: Open ECL IDE, from your Start menu. (Start >> All Programs >> HPCCSystems >> ECL IDE or use the desktop shortcut, if you have created one.)
The Login Window displays.
Provide your credentials (hpccdemo) then press the OK button.
Open a new Builder Window (CTRL+N) and write the following code:OUTPUT('Hello World');
This could also be written as:
'Hello World'; In the second program listing, the OUTPUT keyword is omitted. This is possible because the language is declarative and the OUTPUT action is implicit.
Select thor as your target cluster.

Thor is the Data Refinery component of your HPCC. It is a massively parallel computer cluster, optimized for sorting, manipulating, and transforming massive data. This process is also known as ETL (Extract, Transform, and Load)
Press the syntax check button on the main toolbar (or press F7).

Syntax Check
A successful syntax check displays the "No Errors" message.
Press the Submit button (or press CTRL+ENTER).

Completed job
The green check mark indicates successful completion.
Click on the workunit number tab and then on the Result 1 tab to see the output.

sect1.title: Working with ECL
sect1.para: Now that you have submitted some ECL code, it's time to try some more complex operations.
The following examples are provided to get you started.

sect2.title: ECL Example: Anagram1
sect2.para: This example takes a STRING and produces every possible anagram from it. This code is the basis for a second example which evaluates which of these are actual words using a word list data file.

listitem.para: Select thor as your target cluster.
Press the syntax check button on the main toolbar (or press F7)
Press the Submit button (or press CTRL+ENTER).

Completed job
The green check mark indicates successful completion.
Click on the workunit number tab and then on the Result 1 tab to see the output.

sect2.title: Roxie Example: Anagram2
sect2.para: In this example, we will download an open source data file of dictionary words, spray that file to our Thor cluster, then validate our anagrams against that file so that we determine which are valid words. The validation step uses a JOIN of the anagram list to the dictionary file. Using an index and a keyed join would be more efficient, but this serves as a simple example.

sect3.title: Download the word list
sect3.para: We will download the word list from http://wordlist.sourceforge.net/

listitem.para: Download the Official 12 Dicts Package
Extract the 2of12.txt file to a folder on your local machine. The files are available in tar.gz or ZIP format.

sect3.title: Load the Dictionary File to your Landing Zone
sect3.para: In this step, you will copy the data files to a location from which it can be sprayed to your HPCC cluster. A Landing Zone is a storage location attached to your HPCC. It has a utility running to facilitate file spraying to a cluster.
For smaller data files, maximum of 2GB, you can use the upload/download file utility in ECL Watch. This data file is only ~400 kb.

Next you will distribute (or Spray) the dataset to all the nodes in the HPCC cluster. The power of the HPCC comes from its ability to assign multiple processors to work on different portions of the data file in parallel. Even though the VM Edition only has a single node, the data must be sprayed to the cluster.

listitem.para: In your browser, go to the ECL Watch URL. For example, http://nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn:8010, where nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn is your ESP Server's IP address.

row.entry: Your IP address could be different from the ones provided in the example images. Please use the IP address provided by your installation.

listitem.para: From ECL Watch page, click on the Upload/download File link in the menu on the left side.
Once you click on the Upload/download file link, it will take you to the Dropzones and Files page, where you can choose to Browse your machine for a file to upload:
Press the Browse button to browse the files on your local machine, select the file to upload and then press the Open button.
The file you selected should appear in the Select a file to upload: field. The data file is named: 2of12.txt.
Press on Upload Now to complete the file upload.

sect3.title: Spray the Data File to your Data Refinery (Thor) Cluster
sect3.para: To use the data file in our HPCC system, we must “spray” it to all the nodes. A spray or import is the relocation of a data file from one location (such as a Landing Zone) to multiple file parts on nodes in a cluster.

The distributed or sprayed file is given a logical-file-name as follows: thor::word_list_csv The system maintains a list of logical files and the corresponding physical file locations of the file parts.

listitem.para: Open ECL Watch using the following URL:

para.emphasis: http://nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn:pppp(where nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn is your ESP Server’s IP Address and pppp is the port. The default port is 8010)

listitem.para: CLICK on the Spray Delimited hyperlink under the DFU Files menu on the left.
The DFU Spray Delimited page displays.
Select mydropzone in the Source Machine/dropzone drop list.

The IP Address is automatically filled and the Local Path is partially filled with the default folder on your landing zone. Note: The VM and Community Edition typically only has one landing zone defined.
Complete the Local Path to include the complete file name or use the Choose File button to select the file from a list of files in the folder. The file is 2of12.txt.
Fill in the rest of the parameters (if they are not filled in already).
Max Record Length 8192
Separator \,
Line Terminator \n,\r\n
Quote: '
Fill in the Label using the Logical File name desired: thor::word_list_csv
Make sure the Overwrite and Replicate boxes are checked.
Note: The Replicate option is only available on systems where replication has been enabled.
Press the Submit button
Click the View Progress link
The Workunit progress page displays.
Select thor as your target cluster.
Press the syntax check button on the main toolbar (or press F7)
Press the Submit button.
When it completes, select the Workunit tab, then select the Result tab.
Examine the result.

sect3.title: Compile and Publish the query to Roxie

listitem.para: RT-CLICK on the MyFIles folder in the Repository window, and select Insert Folder from the pop-up menu.
Enter Anagram for the label, then press the OK button.
RT-CLICK on the Anagram Folder, and select Insert File from the pop-up menu.

In the Builder window, in the upper left corner the Submit button has a drop down arrow next to it. Select the arrow to expose the Compile option.
Select Compile
When it completes, select the Workunit tab, then select the Result tab.
When the workunit finishes, it will display a green circle indicating it has compiled.

sect3.title: Publish the Roxie query
sect3.para: Next we will publish the query to a Roxie Cluster.

listitem.para: Select the workunit tab for the ValidateAnagrams that you just compiled.
Select the ECL Watch tab.
Press the Publish button (you may need to scroll down the main window)

Publish Query
When it successfully publishes, you will see:

sect3.title: Run the Roxie Query in WsECL
sect3.para: Now that the query is published to a Roxie cluster, we can run it using the WsECL service Using the following URL:

para.emphasis: http://nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn:pppp (where nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn is your ESP Server’s IP address and pppp is the port. The default port is 8002)

listitem.para: Click on the + sign next to myroxie to expand the tree.
Click on the ValidateAnagrams.1 hyperlink.
The form for the service displays.
Select Output Tables in the drop list.
Provide a word to make anagrams from (e.g., TEACHER), then press the Submit button.
The results display.

sect1.title: Working with data files
sect1.para: Once you start working with your HPCC system, you will want to process some real data, this section shows you how to load data to your HPCC system.

sect2.title: Before you begin
sect2.para: A typical production HPCC system would have much more data capacity than using a virtual system for testing purposes. The size of the file you wish to work with is limited by the size of your virtual machine.

listitem.para: The virtual machine has a limit of 20GB.
The size of the file(s) you can work with in your virtual machine is also limited by your machine's available disk space. Make sure you have adequate disk space available.

row.entry: If you exceed the file size limits your VM state will not be saved and you risk losing your work. Make sure that you have ample space to not only store your data, but your virtual machine's "state" to be able to save your work.

sect2.title: Uploading a file
sect2.para: For smaller data files, maximum of 2GB, you can use the upload/download file utility in ECL Watch.

listitem.para: In your browser, go to the ECL Watch URL displayed (circled in red) in . For example, http://nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn:8010, where nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn is your Virtual Machine's IP address.

row.entry: Your virtual IP address could be different from the ones provided in the example images. Please use the IP address provided by your installation.

listitem.para: From ECL Watch page, click on the Upload/download File link in the menu on the left side.
Once you click on the Upload/download file link, it will take you to the dropzones and files page, where you can choose to Browse your machine for a file to upload:
Press the Browse button to browse the files on your local machine, select the file to upload and then click Open button.
The file you selected should appear in the Select a file to upload field.
Press on Upload Now to complete the file upload.
Now that the file is on your Landing Zone, you can spray the file to your cluster and write ECL code to process it.

sect2.title: Uploading files with a Secure Copy Client
sect2.para: To upload a large file for processing to your virtual machine, you will need a tool that supports the secure copy protocol. In this section, we discuss using WinSCP. There are other tools available, but the steps are similar.

listitem.para: Open the WinSCP tool, and login to your Virtual Machine's IP address using the username and password given.
Once logged in, it should, navigate automatically to the landing zone folder. (/var/lib/HPCCSystems/mydropzone)
Navigate to where your local file is in the left part of the window.
Select the data file to send and copy it to the landing zone, using drag-and-drop.
Now that the file is on your Landing Zone, you can spray the file to your cluster and write ECL code to process it.

sect1.title: Next Steps
sect1.para: Available from the menu in ECL Watch are several documents which provide details on various aspects of the HPCC.
You can also access them from the help menu: Help >> Download Resources.
To familiarize yourself with what your system can do, we recommend:

listitem.para: The HPCC Data Tutorial

This is a simple, step-by-step tutorial that shows the end-to-end process from receiving a receiving a raw data file to publishing a web-based query to search the data. Along the way, you will learn how to process the data, index it, then write and publish a query to search the data. The self-led tutorial and accompanying data file is available on the ECL Watch Resource Page.
The Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon Example
This is a more complex example (*also available on the ECL Watch Resource Page) that uses a database of movie data to find the degree of separation between actors in films.

question.para: Can I run the VM while connected to my network using a Virtual Private network (VPN)?

answer.para: No. Most VPN clients take control of your network device and routing and do not allow split tunnels.

question.para: Can I install this virtual machine on multiple nodes?

answer.para: No. If you want to evaluate a multi-node system, you should use the Community version available from the HPCC Systems Portal at http://hpccsystems.com.

question.para: What are the limits of this version?

answer.para: The HPCC VM Edition runs on a single node, has a limit of 20 GB in it workspace, and doesn't support custom configurations.

question.para: Can I run the VM on my Linux machine?

answer.para: You can run the HPCC VM using the Linux VM Player. The HPCC ECL IDE is a Windows application, but can run under WINE. See the Client Tools Manual for details.

question.para: Can I run the VM on my Mac?

answer.para: Not at this time. There is no Mac version of the VM Player.

question.para: Can I run the VM on my Windows Server?

answer.para: Yes, You can run on Windows Server 2003 or 2008, providing you have access to it using Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).

question.para: Do I need a 64-bit processor to run the VM Edition?

answer.para: No. The VM Player runs in either 32- or 64-bit environments and does not require a 64-bit processor.

question.para: Do I need a 64-bit processor to run the Community Edition?

answer.para: Yes. Community Edition binaries run natively on 64-bit Linux server(s). You can access that HPCC from any Windows workstation (32- or 64-bit) that can run the ECL IDE and a supported browser.

question.para: What happens to my work when I close the virtual machine?

answer.para: The VM Player saves the state of your system when it closes. It saves all of your workunit information, data files, and published query sets as long as there is available space. The maximum size of the saved session is 20 GB.

question.para: Why won't my VM allow access to my network interface?

answer.para: Check your Firewall settings. You may need to disable the Firewall for your VM's network interface.

question.para: Will this version utilize my multi-core processor?

answer.para: This VM is designed to utilize a single core.

question.para: The VM Fails to start on Mac OSx after upgrading to OSx 10.9 Mavericks. How can I correct this?

answer.para: To correct this issue run the following command: sudo launchctl load /Library/LaunchDaemons/org.virtualbox.startup.plist

question.para: Where can I find more information?

answer.para: Visit the HPCC Systems Portal at http://HPCCsystems.com.
